_source.title: Xos: a cry for help
_source.creator_credit: Alan Woodruff, Roberta Chuter and Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School
_source.brief_description: Two transvestite brothers argue over the fate of their deceased grandmother: should she be buried in the family plot, or stuffed and placed beside her favourite dog?

_source.title: Filmo 70DR with light meter
_source.brief_description:
Leather custom case housing a 16mm Bell and Howell Company film camera, and a Weston Master Universal Exposure Meter with 2 accompanying booklets housed in their original cardboard storage box.

Medium/material description (removed from field for XOS data upgrade)
001: Pentagonal shapped leather fitted case and leather strap with a maroon-coloured velvet interior in good condition.
002: Heavy metal body and two lenses.
003 Plastic and metal.
004: Cardboard lid and base.
005: Paper instruction booklet.
006: Paper instruction booklet.
007: Paper

constellations_primary.name: Cities under siege
constellations_primary.description: The Syrian Civil War is an ongoing conflict that is arguably the most documented in history, with images and videos captured by journalists, activists, combatants and victims.

constellations_other.name: Women in charge
constellations_other.description: Across documentary, film, TV, and visual art, Aboriginal women have led how they will be represented on-screen.

constellations_other.name: Skate or die
constellations_other.description: Skateboarding is a subculture frequently documented, from amateur skate videos filmed with fish-eye lenses, to documentaries exploring the genesis of the subculture and gritty feature films depicting underlying social dynamics.

_source.title: The Wedding of Prince Harry and Meghan Markle

constellations_other.name: Royalty, royalty, royalty
constellations_other.description: Fascination with the royal family has persisted over the years, as seen through newsreels, documentaries, films, TV shows, tabloid news and satire.

_source.title_for_label: The Wedding of Prince Harry and Meghan Markle

_source.title: Black Fire (Blackfire)
_source.brief_description: Blackfire is one of the first film ever directed by an Aboriginal person. It is a collection of connected ideas and a take on both the state of Anthropology and Aboriginal Affairs in 1972.

constellations_other.name: Jedda: Uneven ground, the road to on-screen diversity
constellations_other.description: Jedda was the first fully funded Australian feature to be shot on colour film. It was also the first Australian film with Aboriginal actors in lead roles, however, it reflects a deeply problematic time in Australian history.

constellations_other.name: Black Power through film and TV
constellations_other.description: The Black Power movement of the late 1960s and early 70s was “the most exciting and dynamic era in modern Indigenous history” according to Aboriginal activist Professor Gary Foley, who gained widespread attention for protests during the time and later leveraged film and TV to fight for Indigenous rights.

_source.description:
Blackfire is one of the first film ever directed by an Aboriginal person. It is a collection of connected ideas and a take on both the state of Anthropology and Aboriginal Affairs in 1972.

Source: Black Fire (Blackfire) (Film) - Creative Spirits, retrieved from https://www.creativespirits.info/resources/movies/black-fire-blackfire
description_for_label:
Blackfire is one of the first film ever directed by an Aboriginal person. It is a collection of connected ideas and a take on both the state of Anthropology and Aboriginal Affairs in 1972.

Source: Black Fire (Blackfire) (Film) - Creative Spirits, retrieved from https://www.creativespirits.info/resources/movies/black-fire-blackfire

_source.title: You Wreck Me

constellations_other.name: Laughing in the face of adversity
constellations_other.description: Comedy has been used by First Nations storytellers as a tool for social change. On our screens, humour invites audiences to engage with stories and prompts them to grapple with ideas that they otherwise might shy away from.

_source.description: In You Wreck Me, Tony Albert plays on Australia’s self-deprecating humour (known as ‘taking the piss’) to create 50 unique collages that offer a sharp and timely questioning of our national history. Painted up for ceremony, Albert’s political interpretation of Miley Cyrus’ Wrecking Ball ploughs down monuments of Captain Cook, recalling the reductive representations that are often imposed on First Peoples.
description_for_label: In You Wreck Me, Tony Albert plays on Australia’s self-deprecating humour (known as ‘taking the piss’) to create 50 unique collages that offer a sharp and timely questioning of our national history. Painted up for ceremony, Albert’s political interpretation of Miley Cyrus’ Wrecking Ball ploughs down monuments of Captain Cook, recalling the reductive representations that are often imposed on First Peoples.

_source.title: Family Rules

constellations_other.name: Connecting through film
constellations_other.description: Film acts like a time capsule to our collective past. Capturing our most treasured moments with family has never been more accessible, with technology right at our fingers.

_source.description: This up close and personal series gives an exclusive insight into modern Indigenous family life through the eyes of nine sisters and their mother. Angela, Shenika, Helen, Kelly, Kiara, Sharna, Aleisha, Jessica and Hannah navigate their way though adolescence and adulthood as their mother, Daniella, tries to teach them life lessons. With their own unique senses of humour and style, the girls learn to juggle their own aspirations with the reality of everyday life.
description_for_label: This up close and personal series gives an exclusive insight into modern Indigenous family life through the eyes of nine sisters and their mother. Angela, Shenika, Helen, Kelly, Kiara, Sharna, Aleisha, Jessica and Hannah navigate their way though adolescence and adulthood as their mother, Daniella, tries to teach them life lessons. With their own unique senses of humour and style, the girls learn to juggle their own aspirations with the reality of everyday life.

_source.title: Gurrutu’mi Mala (My Connections)

constellations_other.name: Connecting through film
constellations_other.description: Film acts like a time capsule to our collective past. Capturing our most treasured moments with family has never been more accessible, with technology right at our fingers.

_source.description: Gurrutu’mi Mala (My Connections) is about communicating cultural identity and connection. The artist casts himself in this captivating digital video, highlighting the importance of barrkungu wanga (language from a distance) sign language within the everyday life of his Yirrkala community where he works as a cameraman and film editor.
description_for_label: Gurrutu’mi Mala (My Connections) is about communicating cultural identity and connection. The artist casts himself in this captivating digital video, highlighting the importance of barrkungu wanga (language from a distance) sign language within the everyday life of his Yirrkala community where he works as a cameraman and film editor.

_source.title: Innocence Betrayed (2013)

constellations_other.name: Setting the record straight
constellations_other.description: For too long, the history of Australia was only told in mainstream films through a white lens. First Nations people have used the camera as a means of truth-telling and setting the record straight for decades.

_source.description: In 1990 and 1991, three Aboriginal children were murdered in a small country town in Australia. Over 20 years later, the parents of those children are still fighting for justice.
description_for_label: In 1990 and 1991, three Aboriginal children were murdered in a small country town in Australia. Over 20 years later, the parents of those children are still fighting for justice.

_source.title: Kutcha’s Carpool Koorioke
_source.brief_description: Kutcha’s Carpool Koorioke is about strong Aboriginal connection with place and the artists who have songs that have held us, given us strength in the dark times and always brought us together.

constellations_other.name: Canopy
constellations_other.description: John Harvey is a Torres Strait Islander producer, director and writer in screen and stage whose work Canopy celebrates Indigenous self-representation.

_source.description:
Features a stellar musical cast who jump in the car to sing, laugh and share stories. Joining Kutcha in the car this time round are artists Archie Roach, Dan Sultan, Alice Skye, Bart Willoughby, Bunna Lawrie, Emily Wurramara plus Elaine Crombie and local legend and regular passenger Uncle Jack Charles.

Kutcha’s Carpool Koorioke is about strong Aboriginal connection with place and the artists who have songs that have held us, given us strength in the dark times and always brought us together.

  • Kutcha’s Carpool Koorioke website

Joining Kutcha in the car this time round are artists Archie Roach, Dan Sultan, Alice Skye, Bart Willoughby, Bunna Lawrie, Emily Wurramara plus Elaine Crombie and local legend and regular passenger Uncle Jack Charles.

Kutcha’s Carpool Koorioke is about strong Aboriginal connection with place and the artists who have songs that have held us, given us strength in the dark times and always brought us together.

images.credit_line: Kutcha Edwards, Bart Willoughby, Uncle Jack Charles, Elaine Crombie, Bunna Lawrie. Image via Kutcha’s Carpool Koorioke website.

_source.title: I Touch Myself

constellations_other.name: Jan Chapman
constellations_other.description: From an independent Sydney cinema to the world's stage, Jan Chapman's work has many connections to the Australian film scene and Hollywood.

_source.description: The Divnyls’ hit single ‘I Touch Myself’ launched the band’s popularity into the stratosphere, with the single reaching #4 on the US Billboard Hot 100 and number one in Australia. The music video was directed by blockbuster and explosions aficionado Michael Bay and was nominated for three MTV Video Music Awards, including Video of the Year.
description_for_label: The Divnyls’ hit single ‘I Touch Myself’ launched the band’s popularity into the stratosphere, with the single reaching #4 on the US Billboard Hot 100 and number one in Australia. The music video was directed by blockbuster and explosions aficionado Michael Bay and was nominated for three MTV Video Music Awards, including Video of the Year.

images.caption: Chrissy Amphlett in the music video for 'I Touch Myself'. Image via YouTube.
images.credit_line: Chrissy Amphlett in the music video for 'I Touch Myself'. Image via YouTube.

_source.title: Boom Boom Pow -  The Black Eyed Peas (2009)
_source.brief_description: Music video for The Black Eyed Peas hit song Boom Boom Pow.

constellations_other.name: My People
constellations_other.description: The breakout single for Sydney dance duo The Presets, 'My People' was one of the biggest hits of 2007 and propelled by the engaging music video.
